qas.question: How are characters with diacritical marks represented?

answers.text: either as a single precomposed character or as a decomposed sequence of a base letter plus one or more non-spacing marks

qas.question: What encoding does Charis SIL use?
What is the issue with underdots and their placement?
Characters with what marks can be displayed as a single character or a decomposed sequence?
How should the characters with the macron and acute be displayed?
What is the maximum number of non-spacing marks?
What romanization mark is rarely visually incorrect?
What is the name of the rendering technology OpenType uses?
What are rendered identically in practice?
Macrons are used only in what form of Idic?

context: <b8_0>Characters with <a3_0>diacritical marks<b8_0/><a3_0/> can generally be represented <a0_0>either as a single precomposed character or as a decomposed sequence of a base letter plus <b5_0>one<b5_0/> or more non-spacing marks<a0_0/>. For example, ḗ (precomposed e with macron and acute above) and ḗ (e followed by the combining macron above and combining acute above) should be rendered <a4_0>identically<a4_0/>, both appearing as an e with a macron and acute accent, but in practice, their appearance may vary depending upon what rendering engine and fonts are being used to display the characters. Similarly, <b6_0>underdots<b6_0/>, as needed in the <b9_0>romanization<b9_0/> of Indic, will <a2_0>often be placed incorrectly<a2_0/>[citation needed]. Unicode characters that map to precomposed glyphs can be used in many cases, thus avoiding the problem, but where no precomposed character has been encoded the problem can often be solved by using a specialist Unicode font such as <b7_0>Charis SIL<b7_0/> that uses <a1_0>Graphite, OpenType, or AAT technologies<a1_0/> for advanced rendering features.
